Done
Updated. Thanks

I feel this is a better name.. 
handle<redfish schema>Get.. 
So handleSensorGet
Done

Done
can we call this chassisName?
Done
Fixed. Thanks
Done
Why can't you use https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/6dbe9bea2e45791fc924645fb8b7813fdd7f4cd1/redfish-core/include/utils/chassis_utils.hpp#L21 ?
Modified. Thanks
What is the modification that addressed this question?
Modified.Thanks
Done
Can we call this handleChassisNameGet?
Done
Changed back to handleSensorGet and another function name changed to handleChassisNameGet. Thanks
Done

can we call this chassis? Follow Redfish's schema naming here?
getChassisName
Done
Fixed. Thanks
Done

Is this a problem in practice, or just a hypothetical problem?  This was done this way because grabbing sensors happens very often, so doubling up the number of dbus transactions slows things down.  While I'm ok making it work this way, I'd like to see if we can find a way that doesn't add an extra dbus call.

This can be a negative test case or corner test case, where if purposefully or mistakenly trying to get the sensor data or patch the sensor data, by providing wrong ChassisName /redfish/v1/Chassis/XYZ/Sensor/<sensor> (where XYZ is not a valid chassisName) it should give error.
Just to be clear, this is only a test case failure?
Done.
"Done." doesn't answer my question, and I don't see the commit message updated.
Please reply to all comments. :)
Fixed all comments. Thanks
Updated. Thank you
Responded to the review comments. Thanks

I am still confused why this code doesn't look like https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/3e7374243ff53125f3a55c2d0b1927e89261b1f9/redfish-core/lib/thermal_metrics.hpp#L47 

Why doesn't that helper getValidChassisPath function work?

Really we should be using getAssociatedSubTreePaths here, and everywhere we're doing that same compare.

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/3e7374243ff53125f3a55c2d0b1927e89261b1f9/include/dbus_utility.hpp#L212C13-L212C38

Both are same, since we need to get the sensor details after the actual chassisName and user supplied chassis are matching, written own function which handles both (comparing both actual chassisName and chassisId, if both are matching then processing for sensor values in another function in handleSensorNameGet, if not matching returning.
I still don't understand why we don't want to use that common function. Code reuse
I don't think the question is answered here: why a new function is created, why the existing function can't be used here?
Now the code is modified to reuse the function redfish::chassis_utils::getValidChassisPath. Thanks
Done
Should it break if it is not empty?
Modified the code. Thanks
Done

Please make a measurement of how much slower this makes getting all the sensors.  This was intentionally not done this way because chaining two mapper calls is pretty slow, and sensors should be fast.
Will check and Update
Modified the code. There is not much difference in timing with this call.

> There is not much difference in timing with this call.

Considering it's doing double (triple?) the number of dbus calls, I find that hard to believe.  How did you verify there wasn't much timing difference?

Did you try something with $expand depth 2?
modified the code as per the review. Please make review comments as "Resolved" for all the comments (earlier comments) which are agreed or OK. So, that I can work on unresolved comments.
Updated responses to review comments. Thanks
Responded to review comments. Thanks
This looks unrelated to the change in sensorCollection?
This change is for /redfish/v1/Chassis/<STR>/Power/PowerControl/<STR> which is also giving 200 OK without body even if the chassisName is given wrong. This change is in power.hpp
Right.... so it's unrelated to changing sensor collection (which is in sensor.hpp).  Please put it in its own patch (and with its own tests).
Do we have to push the code changes (small change only) required for power.hpp for the issue in another thread.
Code change in power.hpp is removed from here. Updated only for sensor collection.
Done
This code is a callback for an individual sensor, not a sensor Collection.  handleSensorCollectionGet is for the sensor collection.  This should be called doSensor
Will update and push the changes. is the name "doSensorGet" fine.
sure, that's fine, so long as it's not explicitly named the wrong thing (ie, sensor collection when this is not a sensor collection) it's fine.  We're not that consistent on the naming conventions.
will change to either doSensorGet or finishSensorGet and push the code
Modified Code. changed to doSensorGet. Thanks
Done
Fixed review comments and modified code accordingly. Review and approve.
Responded for review comments. Thanks
Please review and approve. Thanks
Please update and provide answers to all the existing open issues.
Responded for review comment. Please review and approve
Replied. Please review and approve.
Modified as per review comments. Review and approve. Thanks
Done. Review and approve.Thanks

It took 2 months for responses to my questions to be posted, please give me a similar amount of time (2 months) to review and approve.

Thanks.

this is now just checking if the chassis is valid?

What if you have

/redfish/v1/Chassis1/Sensors/Sensor1
/redfish/v1/Chassis2/Sensors/Sensor2

Won't

/redfish/v1/Chassis1/Sensors/Sensor2

Still return the same result?

Yes, I could see this would prevent

/redfish/v1/NoExist/Sensors/Sensor2

from returning the right behavior, but shouldn't we handle both cases?

Please add the missing tests cases above to your testing.

Yes. It is tested for all the possible trest cases.
for ex: If we have /redfish/v1/Chassis1/Sensors/Sensor1 and /redfish/v1/Chassis2/Sensors/Sensors2

if /redfish/v1/Chassis1/Sensors/Sensor1 is valid, then /redfish/v1/Chassis2/Sensors/Sensor1 and /redfish/v1/Chassis1/Sensors/Sensor2 are returning error. Even checked for PATCH and POST methods along with GET method.

@SrinivasaRao in Ed's scenario both  /redfish/v1/Chassis1 and  /redfish/v1/Chassis2 are valid path, get /redfish/v1/Chassis1/Sensors/Sensor2 will think chassis is valid and call "doSensorGet" with chassisId=1 and sensorId=2 with valid chassisPath

Have you tested this scenario and confirmed it is working as expected, i.e. /redfish/v1/Chassis1/Sensors/Sensor2 should return NotFound

Yes it is tested.
Chassis is unique to the system.
If suppose Chassis1 and Chassis2 both are valid...but as I tested, Chassis1 or Chassis2  is considered as valid based on the system and not both are valid on the same board.
So chassis is valid and having one valid entity only...So, when /Chassis/<Chassis_ID>/Sensors/<Sensor_Name>  is given from redfish postman tool, it is checking for valid chassis. Once this check is done then it is checking valid sensors in respective chassis.
Sensor Validity is checked in "DoSensorGet" specific to either Chassis1 or Chassis2.
On some system, both Chassis1 and Chassis2 can be valid path, it needs to work correctly also.

Yes..in that case also it will work. Since it is based on user input that is supplied in redfish postman tool. For example, if user supplied https://<BMC_IP>/redfish/v1/Chassis/<ChassisID1>/Sensors/<Sensor1>.Then , first api "requestRoutesSensor" is called which is based on app(user postman tool input) and will directly going call handleSensorGet, where validity of ChassisID(Chassis1 or Chassis2) is checked and once ChassisID is valid, then it is going to check for DoSensorGet (will get the valid sensors for that particular chassis). from the async call 
 redfish::chassis_utils::getValidChassisPath(asyncResp, chassisId,
        std::bind_front(doSensorGet, asyncResp, chassisId, sensorId)); 
        
both getValidChassisPath and doSensorGet are handled together.
